summary.text_en: Thomas Young performed a simple, elegant experiment that settled the century-long debate over whether light was a particle or a wave. He passed a single beam of light through two narrow, parallel slits and observed the pattern on a screen behind them. Instead of two bright lines (as the 'particle' theory would predict), he saw a series of alternating bright and dark 'interference fringes'. This was definitive proof that light behaves as a *wave*, resurrecting Huygens's wave theory (`huygens_wave_theory_1678`) and toppling Newton's particle theory (`newton_opticks_1704`).
key_points_en: Called 'the most beautiful experiment in physics'

story.text_en: Newton's particle theory had reigned for 100 years. It predicted that if you shoot light 'particles' through two slits, you should get *two bright lines* on the screen, like shooting bullets through two holes. Young's experiment showed *multiple* light and dark bands instead. He correctly identified this as 'wave interference': where wave 'crests' from both slits meet, they add up (constructive interference) to make a *bright* fringe. Where a 'crest' meets a 'trough', they cancel each other out (destructive interference), creating a *dark* fringe. His work was viciously attacked and ignored by Newton's supporters at the time.

fun_facts.text_en: Thomas Young was a true 'polymath'. He was a physician, physicist, and linguist who was one of the key figures in *deciphering the Rosetta Stone*.

Ironically, 120 years later when physicists re-did this experiment with 'electrons' (which are definite particles), they *also* got an interference pattern. This became the central paradox of quantum mechanics (wave-particle duality).

simple_explanation.text_en:
Imagine you throw *rocks* (particles) at a barrier with two openings. You'd expect to see *two* impact marks on the back wall.
Now, imagine you send *water waves* at the barrier. When the waves pass through the two slits, they interfere. On the back wall, you'd see a *striped pattern* of big waves (crests meeting crests) and calm water (crests meeting troughs).
Young's experiment showed that light, when passed through two slits, behaves like the *water waves*, not the rocks.

applications.text_en: The double-slit experiment later became the central thought experiment that revealed 'wave-particle duality'â€”the fact that particles like electrons *also* behave as waves.

impact.text_en: Young's double-slit experiment is one of the most important and profound experiments in history. In its day, it definitively 'killed' Newton's 100-year-reign of the particle theory, establishing the wave theory as the new orthodoxy. In the modern era, it became the central paradox for revealing the strangeness of the quantum world (wave-particle duality). Richard Feynman said it contains 'the only mystery' of quantum mechanics.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Huygens (his neglected 'wave theory' was what Young's experiment sought to prove)
Newton (his 'corpuscular theory' was the dominant theory Young sought to disprove)

influenced.contribution_en: Augustin-Jean Fresnel (who provided the rigorous 'quantitative' mathematical framework for Young's 'qualitative' result)
Maxwell (whose theory finally explained *what* the wave was: an electromagnetic wave)
Einstein (his 'photoelectric effect' conversely proved light *also* has particle properties, creating wave-particle duality)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Thomas Young used two simple slits to reveal the deepest wave-nature of light.

quiz.question_en: What phenomenon did Thomas Young observe in his double-slit experiment that proved light was a 'wave'?
options_en: That light travels in straight lines
A pattern of 'interference fringes' (alternating light and dark bands)
quiz.explanation_en: If light were *particles* (like bullets), it would only form *two* bright bands. The *multiple* light-and-dark striped pattern he saw is the unique signature of *waves* adding up (constructive interference) and canceling each other out (destructive interference).
